article.headline: Arkansas 68, Louisiana Tech 56
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- Arkansas has its best start since the 1997-98 season, but players aren't satisfied. The Razorbacks (6-1) used a 23-2 run before halftime to secure a 68-56 victory over Louisiana Tech on Wednesday and then they put everything on cruise control. The Bulldogs (3-3) trailed by 18 at halftime and never cut the margin to less than 12, but Arkansas let them hang around by shooting just 34.8 percent in the second half. "We just have to start putting teams away and not give them a chance to think they even have a chance to be in the game," said sophomore guard Jonathan Modica, who led the Razorbacks in scoring for the seventh straight time with 22 points. Arkansas will need a complete effort on Saturday to improve to 7-1 against Oklahoma State (5-1) and former coach Eddie Sutton in Fayetteville. "It would be good to be 7-1," Modica said. "We've got to buckle down. We've got to play 40 minutes of complete basketball. We have to take advantage of everything they give us. Oklahoma State is a good basketball team. Eddie Sutton is a great coach and he knows how to win." Arkansas coach Stan Heath celebrated his 39th birthday with the victory that gave the Razorbacks their best start since 1997-98, when Nolan Richardson's team opened 8-2 on its way to the tournament. "It seems like every team we've played has been getting better and better, and it's going to continue to get that way," Heath said. "I feel like we're on course. I think it's a good 6-1. I don't think we're playing any cupcakes, and we're playing good quality basketball teams. We're doing what we have to do." Modica had 12 points during the 23-2 run before halftime. Freshman Ronnie Brewer added 14 points, including four dunks. Junior guard Donell Allick led Louisiana Tech with 15 points and junior forward Wayne Powell added 10. The Bulldogs led 23-20 with 6:06 left in the first half after back-to-back baskets by Powell and it looked like they might challenge for their first win in four tries in Arkansas. The Razorbacks shot poorly to start the game, making just 9-of-23 when Powell gave Louisiana Tech its biggest lead. However, the Razorbacks turned up its defensive pressure, spurring the 23-2 run that started with 16 unanswered points. Arkansas made 8 of 11 shots in that time and finished with 18 points off 13 turnovers in the first half. "Turnovers killed us in the first half," Louisiana Tech coach Keith Richard said. "It seems like a lot of them came in the last 5-6 minutes. That was really the story of the game, the last 5-6 minutes of the first half." Rashard Sullivan blocked two shots and his acrobatic putback of a missed layup gave the Razorbacks the lead for good at 24-23. Modica, who had been a second-half player while leading Arkansas in scoring in its first six games, had 16 in the first half. He gave the Razorbacks a 43-25 lead with a pair of free throws with less than a second remaining in the half after making a steal at halfcourt. "We needed to attack the rim more than we did in the first half early," Modica said. "We defended and got on a 16-0 run. They were causing problems, but weren't intense early." Senior guard Charles Tatum also gave Arkansas a lift, hitting one of his two long-range 3-pointers during the run. The senior had his highest minutes total since coming back from tearing three knee ligaments last year and he finished with six points, five rebounds, three assists, two steals and no turnovers. "I am tired after this game, but it feels great to contribute," Tatum said. Louisiana Tech entered the game outrebounding its opponents by 14 per game, but Arkansas, a team without a strong inside game, won that battle, 36-33. This was not the same team Arkansas beat 72-60 last year to start a season-long, four-game winning streak. It lost by just six to Alabama and three to Northern Iowa, a team that knocked off a ranked Iowa team last week. "We were prepared for them, but turnovers killed us," Allick said.
